THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Hibah O. Osman,
      M.D., Respondent/Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, South Carolina State Board of Medical Examiners, Appellant/Respondent.
			
		
	


Carolyn C. Matthews, Administrative Law Court
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  26641
Heard January 6, 2009 - Filed April 27,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Kenneth
  P. Woodington, of Davidson & Lindemann, and Lynne W. Rogers, of South Carolina
  Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, both of Columbia, for
  Appellant-Respondent.
				F.
  Barron Grier, III, and Lauri Soles Darwin, both of Grier Law Firm, of West Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â Â Â Â Â  In
  this medical disciplinary proceeding, the State Board of Medical Examiners of
  the South Carolina Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation (the Board)
  issued an order finding Dr. Hibah O. Osmanâ€™s conduct in performing a surgical
  procedure warranted the issuance of a public reprimand, the imposition of
  costs, and the proviso that Dr. Osman must meet certain requirements to
  reestablish her competency if she ever returned to the practice of surgical
  obstetrics in South Carolina.Â  On appeal, the Administrative Law Court (ALC)
  upheld the public reprimand and costs but struck the competency requirement
  holding the requirement was an â€œanticipatory suspension.â€Â  The Board and Dr.
  Osman filed cross-appeals.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
I.
Dr.
  Osman is a physician licensed by the State Board of Medical Examiners to
  practice family medicine in South Carolina.Â  In July 2002, she was practicing
  in Allendale, South Carolina.Â  One of Dr. Osmanâ€™s patients was expecting her
  third child.Â  The thirty-nine year old patient and her husband wanted the child
  to be born in Allendale, apparently to minimize the inconvenience and
  disruption to the husbandâ€™s motel business during a busy holiday season. Â Dr.
  Osman acquiesced in this request, although the patient suffered from placenta
  previa, which is an anterior, low-lying placenta possibly covering a portion of
  the opening to the womb.
Dr.
  Osman began the Caesarean section (hereinafter C-Section).Â  Epidural anesthesia
  was attempted multiple times without success.Â  Therefore, general anesthesia
  was administered.Â  Unbeknownst to Dr. Osman, the Certified Registered Nurse
  Anesthetist (CRNA) was unable to intubate the patient.Â  During the surgery, the
  placenta bled heavily and hampered Dr. Osmanâ€™s ability to deliver the baby.Â  This
  difficulty caused Dr. Osman to lengthen her incision multiple times.Â  The baby
  was successfully delivered, but one of the lengthening incisions injured the
  patientâ€™s uterine artery.Â  This injury was not detected by Dr. Osman during the
  surgery.Â  The damage to the artery and the placenta abnormality led to
  significant bleeding and declining vital signs.
As
  the patientâ€™s vital signs deteriorated, Dr. Osman instructed staff to contact
  Dr. Ross, a local surgeon.Â  Dr. Ross, however, was away on a planned vacation.Â 
  Dr. Osman failed to ensure the availability of a surgeon in case of
  complications.Â  Due to the deteriorating circumstances, Dr. Osman contacted Dr.
  Johnson at MUSC.Â  The patient was transferred to MUSC by helicopter.Â  At MUSC,
  Dr. Johnson conducted an ultrasound and immediately began operating on the
  patient.Â  While operating, significant bleeding was observed.Â  A total
  abdominal hysterectomy was performed.Â  The patient remained at the hospital for
  seven days following surgery and was discharged.Â  Despite the positive results,
  all parties agree, the patient was very close to death.
This
  disciplinary action followed when the Board filed a formal complaint against Dr. Osman alleging approximately
  thirteen deviations from the standard of care. Â Dr. Osman filed a pro se response admitting to three instances of misconduct alleged in the complaint:
  inappropriately performing the surgery in a community county hospital with
  limited resources, failing to ensure surgical backup, and failing to obtain
  proper written consent.
Both
  the Disciplinary Panel for the Board and Board found misconduct as to those matters
  conceded by Dr. Osman. Â In its report, the panel recommended no sanction be
  issued. Â However, the Board elected to publically reprimand Dr. Osman, require
  Dr. Osman to pay the assessed costs associated
  with adjudicating the case, and restrict
  Dr. Osman from the practice of surgical obstetrics until Dr. Osman proves she
  has the appropriate education and training.Â  Dr. Osman returned to her native Lebanon.
On
  appeal, the ALC affirmed the public reprimand and imposition of costs.Â  The ALC,
  however, deleted the provision requiring Dr. Osman to establish competency in
  surgical obstetrics on the basis that â€œan anticipatory suspension is a sanction
  that the Board does not have the authority to impose.â€Â  The Board and Dr. Osman filed cross appeals challenging
  the ALCâ€™s order.Â  These appeals are before us pursuant to Rule 204(b)
  certification.

II.
The Boardâ€™s Appeal
The Board argues
  the ALC erred in striking the reestablishment of competency condition.Â  We
  agree.
Section 40-1-120(A)(3) of the South Carolina Code (2001)
  authorizes the Board to â€œplace a licensee on probation or restrict or suspend
  the individualâ€™s license for a definite or indefinite time and prescribe
  conditions to be met during probation, restriction, or suspension including,
  but not limited to, satisfactory completion of additional education, of a
  supervisory period, or of continuing education programs.â€Â  The Boardâ€™s order contained
  the following competency reestablishment clause:

	If [Dr. Osman] should ever return to active practice
  in the State of South Carolina, [Dr. Osman] shall be restricted from the
  practice of surgical obstetrics until such time as [Dr. Osman] provides proof
  that is satisfactory to the Board that she has appropriate education and
  training in this area.

This sanction fits
  squarely within the parameters of the Boardâ€™s statutory authority.Â  Therefore,
  the ALC erred when it struck the reestablishment provision after improperly
  finding the Board did not have the authority to levy this sanction.Â  We note,
  however, were Dr. Osman to provide the Board with proof of her competence, the
  decision to find this proof to be satisfactory should be made objectively and
  reasonably.Â  Approval cannot be unreasonably withheld.
As the Board did
  not exceed its statutory authority in imposing this sanction, we reverse the ALC on this issue and reinstate the competency reestablishment provision.[1]
III.
Dr. Osmanâ€™s Appeal
In
  her cross-appeal, Dr. Osman argues the ALC erred in imposing a public reprimand
  and responsibility for the costs of the proceedings because her actions did not
  violate the rules of ethical conduct and there is no substantial evidence in
  the record to support these sanctions.Â  We disagree as there is substantial
  evidence to support the Boardâ€™s findings.
A party aggrieved
  by the decision of the Board may appeal to the ALC.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-1-160
  (2001).Â  The review is governed by section 1-23-380 of the Administrative Procedures
  Act (APA).Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation
    v. Girgis, 332 S.C. 162, 166, 503 S.E.2d 490, 491-92 (Ct. App. 1998).Â 
  Under the APA, the reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of
  the agency on questions of fact, but may reverse the agencyâ€™s decision if the
  decision is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(5) (Supp. 2008).
Here, Dr. Osman, in
  a letter to the Board, agreed with three of the Boardâ€™s allegations: use of a
  hospital with inadequate resources, failure to ensure proper surgical backup,
  and failure to provide written informed consent.Â  Specifically, Dr. Osman
  agreed, â€œit was inappropriate . . . to perform a primary C-Section in a
  community county hospital setting without adequate resources immediately
  available, i.e.: blood products and surgical backup.â€Â  Additionally, Dr. Osman
  agreed that she â€œfailed to have surgery stand-by at the bedside in the event
  that hysterectomy became necessary.Â  When Dr. Ross was called by [Dr. Osman] .
  . . it was learned that Dr. Ross was away on vacation and not available.Â 
  Therefore, Dr. Osman essentially had no surgical backup in the event that a
  hysterectomy became necessary.â€Â  Lastly, Dr. Osman agreed she â€œdeviated from
  the appropriate standard of care by failing to provide written informed consent
  to [a] patient . . . as to the possible complications and difficulties which
  can occur with C-Section in a patient with placenta previa.â€
Although
  Dr. Osman disputed the many other allegations made by the Board in the
  complaint, Dr. Osmanâ€™s three concessions constitute substantial evidence in
  support of the Boardâ€™s actions.Â  Further, the Disciplinary Panel for the Board
  and the Board both limited the finding of misconduct to the three admitted
  deviations from the standard of care.
When
  reviewing the Boardâ€™s opinion, the ALC observed:Â  â€œThe Boardâ€™s public reprimand
  of [Dr. Osman] for her lack of good judgment is well within its sanctioning
  authority under Section 40-47-200,[2] and [Dr. Osman] has not demonstrated that, in exercising that authority, the
  Board acted arbitrarily or discriminatorily.â€Â  The ALC concluded that Dr. Osman
  â€œha[d] not established any sufficient grounds upon which to disturb the
  sanction imposed by the Board.â€
We
  agree with the conclusion of the ALC that substantial evidence supports the
  Boardâ€™s decision.Â  While we recognize Dr. Osmanâ€™s overall competence and her
  understandable desire to avoid the public reprimand, the sanction imposed by
  the Board is well within the Boardâ€™s statutory authority.Â  Because Dr. Osman
  has shown no basis for overturning the Boardâ€™s decision, we affirm this issue.
IV.
We
  affirm the ALCâ€™s holding that substantial evidence supports the public
  reprimand and costs.Â  We reverse the ALCâ€™s striking of the reestablishment of
  competency provision, and we reinstate the provision.Â  The judgment of the ALC
  is 
AFFIRMED IN
  PART; REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1]Â 
  The Board also disputed whether Dr. Osman initially appealed the imposition of
  the competency provision to the ALC. Â The Board therefore argued the ALC
  improperly struck the provision sua sponte. Â Dr. Osman seized upon this
  allegation and countered that if the competency provision were not part of her
  appeal from the Board, then the Board failed to preserve this issue in a motion
  for reconsideration. Â Upon careful review and a fair reading of the record, we
  hold this issue was properly preserved for our review.
[2]Â  The ALC cited section 40-47-200 of the South
  Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  This section has been amended and a similar
  provision that allows the Board to order additional training is now found at
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-47-120(A) (Supp. 2008).

				The State, Respondent,

				Gary A. White, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26642
Heard February 4, 2009 - Filed April 27,

				Appellate

  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant

  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  We
  granted a writ of certiorari to review a court of appeals opinion upholding the
  admissibility of Rule 702, SCRE, expert testimony related to dog tracking
  evidence. Â State v. White, 372 S.C. 364, 642 S.E.2d 607 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We affirm the court of appeals in result.
I.
This case arises from an armed robbery of a convenience
  store in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  After midnight on April 19, 2004, Gary
  White and Anthony Morris were riding in a car driven by Roy Wiggins.Â  As
  Wiggins drove past a convenience store, White told Wiggins to turn around and
  go back to the store.Â  Wiggins complied.Â  Wiggins drove to the store and parked
  behind it.Â  White and Morris exited the car, with Wiggins staying behind in the
  driverâ€™s seat.Â  White was carrying a gun.Â  
White and Morris
  entered the convenience store.Â  Gwen Anthony, the store manager, was restocking
  the grill area when White and Morris entered suddenly.Â  Anthony described the
  robbersâ€™ entry as a â€œflash.â€Â  
White, armed with
  the gun, grabbed Anthony, put his arm around her, and pointed the gun to her
  neck.Â  Morris moved through the store stealing cash, lottery tickets and an
  18-pack of beer while White continued to hold Anthony at gunpoint.Â  While Morris
  was at the beer cooler, White, while standing up, apparently lost
  consciousness. Â 
Anthony testified that
  Whiteâ€™s head fell to her shoulder, and the gun dropped from her neck.Â  Although
  he was unconscious for only a few seconds, Anthony observed that Whiteâ€™s breath
  smelled like alcohol, his gun was black with a silver top, and his jeans were
  baggy and dark in color.Â  With the 18-pack of beer in hand, Morris ran up the
  aisle toward the door and screamed at White, waking him.Â  White, still holding Anthony,
  returned the gun to her neck and began to move toward the door, forcing her to
  accompany him.Â  As they exited the store, White pushed Anthony away and ran in
  the opposite direction.Â  At that very moment, Officer Rouppasong of the
  Columbia Police Department pulled into the store parking lot on a routine
  break.Â  
Upon his arrival on
  the scene, Officer Rouppasong saw two people: Anthony, waving and flagging him
  down and another person running away from the store.Â  Rouppasong described the
  man he saw running as a black male, wearing a white t-shirt and dark colored
  pants, holding or carrying something in one of his hands.Â  Rouppasong remained
  in his vehicle and followed White.Â  As he followed him around the corner of the
  store, Rouppasong saw a car parked on the street.Â  Rouppasong saw a black male
  (later identified as White) exit the car on the passenger side and flee.Â  Rouppasong
  did not give chase; instead, he stayed with the vehicle and Wiggins.Â  Officer
  Gunter, with the K9 unit, was called to the scene to search for the suspect.Â  
Officer Gunter
  arrived on the scene approximately thirty minutes after the robbery.Â  Once
  there, Rouppasong relayed the necessary information that allowed Gunter to know
  where to initiate the track. Â Gunter and his tracking dog, Aurie, began
  tracking and soon found White nearby sleeping next to some bushes, gun in hand.Â 
  Rouppasong testified that the man he saw lying by the bushes, asleep, was the
  same man he saw exiting the store and fleeing the crime scene.Â  There were two
  other in-court eyewitness identifications of White.Â  Wiggins testified that
  White left his car with a gun, returned to his car a short time later, and then
  fled when police arrived.Â  The second identification came from Morris.
White was convicted
  of two counts of armed robbery and kidnapping; he was sentenced to life without
  parole.[1]Â 
  The court of appeals affirmed, rejecting the contention that dog tracking evidence
  must satisfy the standard for â€œscientific basedâ€ expert testimony under State
    v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120 (1979).Â  The court of appeals noted
  a distinction between two types of expert testimony, â€œscientific evidence
  versus experience-based knowledge.â€ Â White, 372 S.C. at 381, 642 S.E.2d
  at 615.Â  With regard to nonscientific expert testimony (which includes dog
  tracking evidence), the court of appeals found that â€œquestions about the reliability
  of [the dog handler] go only to the weight [of his testimony], but not
  admissibility.â€Â  Id. at 376, 642 S.E.2d at 613.Â  Because of the
  suggestion that an initial determination of reliability is not part of the
  trial courtâ€™s gatekeeping role, we granted Whiteâ€™s petition for a writ of
  certiorari.[2]Â Â  
II.
A.
A trial courtâ€™s decision to admit or exclude expert
  testimony will not be reversed absent a prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  State
    v. Price, 368 S.C. 494, 498, 629 S.E.2d 363, 365 (2006).Â  
White concedes the dog handler met the Rule 702, SCRE, qualifications
  due to his experience and training.[3]Â 
  White contends the trial court failed in its gatekeeping role to vet the
  reliability of the dogâ€™s tracking skills, thus leaving the jury to speculate
  about the dogâ€™s reliability.Â  We agree with Whiteâ€™s premise that all expert
  testimony under Rule 702, SCRE, imposes on the trial courts an affirmative and
  meaningful gatekeeping duty.Â  To the extent the court of appeals opinion may be
  construed as excluding a gatekeeping role for trial courts in connection with nonscientific
  (or experienced based)[4] expert testimony, such construction is rejected.
All expert testimony must satisfy the Rule 702 criteria, and that
  includes the trial courtâ€™s gatekeeping function in ensuring the proposed expert
  testimony meets a reliability threshold for the juryâ€™s ultimate consideration.Â 
  Rule 702 provides:

	If scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will
  assist the trier of fact to understand the evidence or to determine a fact in
  issue, a witness qualified as an expert by knowledge, skill, experience,
  training, or education, may testify thereto in the form of an opinion or
  otherwise.

â€œThis language
  makes no relevant distinction between â€˜scientificâ€™ knowledge and â€˜technicalâ€™ or
  â€˜other specializedâ€™ knowledge.Â  It makes clear that any such knowledge might
  become the subject of expert testimony. . . .Â  Hence, as a matter of language,
  the Rule applies its reliability standard to all â€˜scientific,â€™ â€˜technical,â€™ or
  â€˜other specializedâ€™ matters within its scope.â€Â  Kumho Tire Co., Ltd. v.
    Carmichael, 526 U.S. 137, 147 (1999).Â  Reliability is a central feature of
  Rule 702 admissibility, and our jurisprudence is in complete accord.Â  State
    v. Jones, 343 S.C. 562, 572, 541 S.E.2d 813, 818 (2001) (finding error in
  the trial courtâ€™s decision to admit â€œunreliableâ€ expert evidence); State v.
    Council, 335 S.C. 1, 20, 515 S.E.2d 508, 518 (1999) (noting that before
  expert evidence is admitted the trial court must determine it is reliable). 
With regard to dog tracking evidence, this Courtâ€™s jurisprudence (even
  prior to the adoption of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence in 1995) speaks
  to the reliability foundational requirement of such evidence.Â  State v.
    Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 476-77, 385 S.E.2d 839, 842-43 (1989) (finding no
  abuse of discretion in trial courtâ€™s admission of dog tracking testimony where a
  deputy sheriff had â€œâ€˜runâ€™â€ bloodhounds for eleven years and finding of
  reliability supported by â€œdogs . . . characteristics of acuteness in scent as
  well as the power of discrimination between human and other scentsâ€); State
    v. Brown, 103 S.C. 437, 444, 88 S.E. 21, 23 (1916) (finding trial courtâ€™s
  admission of dog tracking evidence constituted an abuse of discretion where
  evidence established that the dog tracking occurred outside the â€œperiod of
  efficiencyâ€ and was therefore unreliable).Â Â  Â 
While we agree with White concerning the important gatekeeping
  role of the trial court in determining the admissibility of expert testimony
  under Rule 702, the trial court properly discharged its duty in this case.Â  As
  noted, White concedes the qualifications of Officer Gunter as a dog handler.Â 
  Whiteâ€™s argument is that the dog tracking evidence is unreliable.Â  The trial
  court permitted a thorough examination of all matters relating to
  admissibility, including reliability. 
Beyond Officer Gunterâ€™s extensive training and experience, there
  was ample evidence concerning the training and reliability of the dog, Aurie.Â 
  Aurie is a German shepherd that descended from a bloodline of known police and
  military working dogs.Â  Through testing, Aurie has been certified in several
  areas of tracking, yet Aurieâ€™s strongest skill is tracking people.Â  Officer
  Gunter and Aurie, as of the trial, had been â€œpartnersâ€ in excess of seven years
  and had accomplished approximately 750 tracks together.Â  The finding of
  reliability is well supported by the record, and we find no abuse of discretion
  in the admission of the dog tracking evidence.
In addition to the trial courtâ€™s discharge of its gatekeeping role
  in assessing the admissibility of the dog tracking evidence, the court properly
  instructed the jury that â€œyou are to give his testimony such weight and
  credibility as you deem appropriate as you will with any and all witnesses that
  will testify in this trial.â€
B.
The court of appeals is commended for its thorough analysis of our
  countryâ€™s jurisprudence concerning dog tracking evidence.Â  While foundational
  requirements vary, â€œan overwhelming number [of jurisdictions] allow admission
  of dog tracking evidence in a criminal case to prove identity.â€Â  White,
  372 S.C. at 378, 642 S.E.2d at 614.Â  To provide uniformity, we think it
  advisable to adopt the following evidentiary framework to guide our bench and
  bar concerning dog tracking evidence.Â  By extrapolating from our case law and
  other authorities, we conclude a sufficient foundation for the admission of dog
  tracking evidence is established if (1) the
  evidence shows the dog handler satisfies the qualifications of an expert under
  Rule 702; (2) the evidence shows the dog is of a breed characterized by an
  acute power of scent; (3) the dog has been trained to follow a trail by scent;
  (4) by experience the dog is found to be reliable; (5) the dog was placed on
  the trail where the suspect was known to have been within a reasonable time;
  and (6) the trail was not otherwise contaminated.  See State v. Childs, 299 S.C. at 476-77, 385 S.E.2d at 842-43; State v. Brown, 103 S.C. at 443-45, 88 S.E. at 22-23; see also State
    v. Taylor, 447 S.E.2d 360, 368-69 (N.C. 1994); Jay M. Zitter, Annotation, Evidence of Trailing by
      Dogs in Criminal Cases, 81 A.L.R. 5th 563 (2000).
C.
The case before us may appear straightforward, especially in light
  of the overwhelming evidence of guilt.Â  Yet on appeal the State has persisted
  with the argument that reliability need not be shown for the admission of
  nonscientific expert testimony.Â  Because the court of appeals in this case has
  approvingly cited State v. Morgan, 326 S.C. 503, 485 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App.
  1997) in support of the Stateâ€™s position, we believe clarification of the
  analytical framework for the admissibility of nonscientific expert testimony is
  warranted.
At oral argument, the State argued this Court need not concern
  itself with the issue of reliability because the case only involves
  nonscientific expert testimony.Â  Presumably, the State relies on the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision in State v. Morgan, which held â€œ[i]f the expertâ€™s opinion does not fall within [the] Jones[5] [standard for scientific expert testimony], questions about the reliability of
  an expertâ€™s methods go only to the weight, but not admissibility, of the
  testimony.â€ Morgan, 326 S.C. at 513, 485 S.E.2d at 118.Â  This is an
  incorrect statement of law.Â  
We
  overrule Morgan to the extent it suggests that only scientific expert
  testimony must pass a threshold reliability determination by the trial court
  prior to its admission in evidence.[6]Â 
  The familiar tenet of evidence law that a continuing challenge to evidence goes
  to â€œweight, not admissibilityâ€ has never been intended to supplant the
  gatekeeping role of the trial court in the first instance in assessing the
  admissibility of expert testimony, including the threshold determination of
  reliability.Â  Nonscientific expert testimony must satisfy Rule 702, both in
  terms of expert qualifications and reliability of the subject matter.
Courts
  are often presented with challenges on both frontsâ€”qualifications and
  reliability.Â  The party offering the expert must establish that his witness has
  the necessary qualifications in terms of â€œknowledge, skill, experience,
  training or education.â€ Â Rule 702, SCRE.Â  With respect to qualifications, a
  witness may satisfy the Rule 702 threshold yet the opponent may still challenge
  the amount or quality of the qualifications.Â  It is in this latter context that
  the trial court properly concludes that â€œdefects in the amount and quality of
  education or experience go to the weight to be accorded the expertâ€™s testimony
  and not its admissibility.â€ State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 256, 391
  S.E.2d 551, 554 (1990). Â Turning to the reliability factor, a trial court may
  ultimately take the same approach, but only after making a threshold
  determination for purposes of admissibility.
State
  v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) is often cited for the gatekeeping role of the trial
  court with regard to expert testimony under Rule 702, as well as the standard
  reliability factors for scientific evidence.[7]Â 
  The foundational reliability requirement for expert testimony does not lend
  itself to a one-size-fits-all approach, for the Council factors for scientific
  evidence serve no useful analytical purpose when evaluating nonscientific
  expert testimony.Â  We have set forth above foundational requirements for Rule
  702 expert testimony concerning dog tracking evidence.
We
  do not pretend to know the myriad of Rule 702 qualification and reliability
  challenges that could arise with respect to nonscientific expert evidence.Â 
  Consequently, we offer no formulaic approach that will apply in the generality
  of cases.Â  Yet the trial court in the discharge of its gatekeeping role in
  determining admissibility must initially answer the always present threshold
  questions of qualification and reliability.
III.
We
  hold that the trial courts of this state have a gatekeeping role with respect
  to all evidence sought to be admitted under Rule 702, whether the evidence is
  scientific or nonscientific.Â  In the discharge of its gatekeeping role, a trial
  court must assess the threshold foundational requirements of qualifications and
  reliability and further find that the proposed evidence will assist the trier
  of fact.Â  The familiar evidentiary mantra that a challenge to evidence goes to
  â€œweight, not admissibilityâ€ may be invoked only after the trial court has
  vetted the matters of qualifications and reliability and admitted the evidence.
We
  affirm the court of appeals in result.Â  The trial court properly discharged its
  gatekeeping role in assessing the dog tracking evidence under Rule 702, as to
  qualifications and reliability.Â  
AFFIRMED
  IN RESULT.Â  
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur.


[1]  Whiteâ€™s criminal history triggered a life without parole sentence
  pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003).
[2]  White also asked the court of appeals to grant him a new trial based on
  newly discovered evidence.Â  It appears the new trial motion was not presented
  to the trial court.Â  Moreover, White did not ask the court of appeals to remand
  the new trial motion to the trial court.Â  See State v. Mercer, 381 S.C.
  149, 165-66, 672 S.E.2d 556, 564-65 (2009) (recognizing that a motion for a new
  trial based upon after discovered evidence must be presented to the trial court
  in the first instance).Â  The court of appeals declined to address the issue
  â€œbecause it ha[d] not been raised to and ruled on by the trial court and [wa]s
  not properly before th[e] court.â€Â  White, 372 S.C. at 387, 642 S.E.2d at
  619.Â  We affirm the court of appeals on this issue.Â  Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.Â 
  The disposition of this issue is without prejudice to White seeking such relief
  in the trial court.
[3]  There is likewise no challenge to the Rule 702 criteria that the
  evidence â€œwill assist the trier of fact to understand
  the evidence or to determine a fact in issue.â€ 
[4]  We note that case law uses the terms nonscientific expert testimony and
  experienced based expert testimony interchangeably.Â  For consistency, we will
  use the term nonscientific expert testimony.
[5]  State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120 (1979).
[6]  Morgan relies on this Courtâ€™s opinions in State v. Schumpert,
  312 S.C. 502, 435 S.E.2d 859 (1993) and State v. Whaley, 305 S.C. 138,
  406 S.E.2d 369 (1991) to support its finding that only scientific expert
  testimony includes reliability as part of the foundation for admission in
  evidence.Â  Schumpert and Whaley stand for no such proposition.Â  Schumpert addressed the qualifications of a proposed mental health professional and her
  ability to give expert testimony on rape trauma syndrome.Â  Whaley dealt
  with the admissibility of a proposed expert in eyewitness identifications.Â 
  Because the area of expertise was â€œdistinguishable from â€˜scientificâ€™ evidence,â€
  the State v. Jones scientific framework was not appropriate.Â  Whaley,
  305 S.C. at 142, 406 S.E.2d at 371-72.Â  The Whaley Court further
  observed, â€œ[a]lthough we are of the opinion that this type of testimony need
  not be subjected to the Jones test, we reject any contention that it
  does not comport with Jones.â€Â  Id. at 142 n.2, 406 S.E.2d at 372
  n.2.Â Â  Whaley then proceeded to analyze the matter of reliability and
  held, in the factual context presented, the trial court abused its discretion
  by excluding the expertâ€™s testimony.Â  Id. at 143, 406 S.E.2d at 372.Â  In
  short, neither Schumpert nor Whaley contains the slightest hint
  that a trial court may ignore the question of reliability when considering the
  admissibility of nonscientific expert testimony. 
[7]  The State v. Council factors for scientific expert testimony are: (1) the
  publications and peer review of the technique; (2) prior application of the
  method to the type of evidence involved in the case; (3) the quality control
  procedures used to ensure reliability; and (4) the consistency of the method
  with recognized scientific laws and procedures.Â
